citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The facility does not have a written Program of Veterinary Care (APHIS form 7002). The facility does work with a
veterinarian who regularly visits the facility. A written Program of Veterinary Care ensures APHIS officials can verify that
the facility is using the appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries as directed to
them by the attending veterinarian. Correct by having the attending veterinarian develop a written Program of Veterinary
Care and have this document maintained at the facility and available during inspections by APHIS officials. Correct by:
March 22, 2024.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
Although the facility provides enrichment to the birds, they do not have a written environmental enhancement plan in
place to promote the overall psychological well-being of the birds at the facility. Licensed facilities must develop,
document, and follow a species appropriate plan for environmental enhancement to promote the psychological well-being
of the birds that is within industry standards and approved by the attending veterinarian. This plan must address social
grouping; environmental enrichment; special considerations for young birds (nestlings, fledglings, etc), birds showing
psychological distress through behavior or appearance, and individually housed social species of birds that cannot see or
hear birds of compatible species. This plan must be made available for future inspections. Correct by: March 22, 2024.

citations.desc: Primary enclosures used to transport live birds.
citations.narrative:
The facility’s transport enclosure does not have proper labeling. Proper labeling of an enclosure is important for the safety
of the animals during transportation, and especially should an emergency arise. The words “Live Animals” need to be
clearly marked in letters at least 1-inch high, along with an arrow indicating the correct upright position, on at least one
side and on top of the transport enclosure. Correct by: March 22, 2024.

citations.desc: Primary enclosures used to transport live birds.
citations.narrative:
The facility’s transport enclosure does not have adequate ventilation openings. The transport enclosure has ventilation
openings on only the top surface. Proper ventilation is important during transportation to ensure comfort, proper air
circulation, and temperature regulation to the animals housed within. Since the transport enclosure is not permanently
affixed to the conveyance (truck/van, etc), there must be ventilation openings located on two vertical walls of the
enclosure that are at least 16% of the surface area of each wall, or ventilation openings on all four walls that are at least
8% of the total surface area of each wall. Correct by: March 22, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.40(a)(1) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The facility does not have a written Program of Veterinary Care (APHIS form 7002). The facility does work with a 
veterinarian who regularly visits the facility. A written Program of Veterinary Care ensures APHIS officials can verify that 
the facility is using the appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries as directed to 
them by the attending veterinarian. Correct by having the attending veterinarian develop a written Program of Veterinary 
Care and have this document maintained at the facility and available during inspections by APHIS officials. Correct by: 
March 22, 2024. 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
Although the facility provides enrichment to the birds, they do not have a written environmental enhancement plan in 
place to promote the overall psychological well-being of the birds at the facility. Licensed facilities must develop, 
document, and follow a species appropriate plan for environmental enhancement to promote the psychological well-being 
of the birds that is within industry standards and approved by the attending veterinarian. This plan must address social 
grouping; environmental enrichment; special considerations for young birds (nestlings, fledglings, etc), birds showing 
psychological distress through behavior or appearance, and individually housed social species of birds that cannot see or 
hear birds of compatible species. This plan must be made available for future inspections. Correct by: March 22, 2024. 
3.162(a)(6) 
   
Primary enclosures used to transport live birds. 
The facility’s transport enclosure does not have proper labeling. Proper labeling of an enclosure is important for the safety 
of the animals during transportation, and especially should an emergency arise. The words “Live Animals” need to be 
clearly marked in letters at least 1-inch high, along with an arrow indicating the correct upright position, on at least one 
side and on top of the transport enclosure. Correct by: March 22, 2024. 
3.162(b)(1) 
   
Primary enclosures used to transport live birds.

The facility’s transport enclosure does not have adequate ventilation openings. The transport enclosure has ventilation 
openings on only the top surface. Proper ventilation is important during transportation to ensure comfort, proper air 
circulation, and temperature regulation to the animals housed within. Since the transport enclosure is not permanently 
affixed to the conveyance (truck/van, etc), there must be ventilation openings located on two vertical walls of the 
enclosure that are at least 16% of the surface area of each wall, or ventilation openings on all four walls that are at least 
8% of the total surface area of each wall. Correct by: March 22, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
